“Proudly stands our Alma Mater, as the years roll by…” In this campus view, the entrance to the Student Center, in Alumni Memorial Hall, appears in the foreground, and the clocktower of Kirkland Hall rises high against the sky.
Kirkland Hall, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tenn., home of the Commodores. Kirkland Hall is the Administration Building for Vanderbilt University.
KIRKLAND HALL. Vanderbilt University. Nashville, Tennessee.
KIRKLAND HALL. Vanderbilt University. Nashville, Tennessee.
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240

KIRKLAND HALL. Main administration building of the University. Completed in 1875. Named for Vanderbilt’s second chancellor James H. Kirkland, and his wife. Burned in 1905 and rebuilt. Restoration of the building was begun in 1982. Photo by John Halliburton.
Benson Science Hall, Vanderbilt University. Photo by Will and Deni McIntyre.
Kirkland Hall Tower. Vanderbilt University. Photo by Will and Deni McIntyre.
Vanderbilt University campus with Kirkland tower in the background. Photo by Will and Deni McIntyre.
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN. 37240

unittitle.emph: Furman Hall, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tennessee.

did.unittitle: Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240
FURMAN HALL houses the humanities. Built in 1907, named for Francis Furman, Nashville dry-goods merchant. Remodeled in 1967. Photo by John Halliburton.
JOINT UNIVERSITY LIBRARY, NASHVILLE, TENN.
41–Joint University Library, Nashville, Tenn.
Peabody College, Scarritt College, Vanderbilt University
THE JOINT UNIVERSITY LIBRARY
NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE
The Joint University Library is operated by Peabody University, Scarritt College, and Vanderbilt University. It is the first co-operative University Library project established in America.
Neely Auditorium Vanderbilt University
Nashville, Tennessee
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240
NEELY AUDITORIUM, home of the Vanderbilt University Theatre. Was an auditorium for University assemblies until converted to a theatre in 1976. Photo by Gerald Holly.
Vanderbilt Hospital, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tenn.
VANDERBILT HOSPITAL- VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY- NASHVILLE, TENN.- 78
Vanderbilt Hospital, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tennessee

The Vanderbilt University School of Medicine and Hospital consists of a series of nine buildings brought together under one roof. This group of adjoining units contains the laboratories of the departments of the Medical School, lecture rooms, administrative offices, library and various subdivisions of the hospital. They also include the large department for out-patients and 200 beds.
THE VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AND HOSPITAL
THE VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AND HOSPITAL
Nashville, Tennessee
THE VANDERBILT SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AND HOSPITAL
Nashville, Tennessee
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240
Doorway of GODCHAUX HALL, Vanderbilt School of Nursing. Named for Mary Ragland Godchaux. Photo by Gary Gore.
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240
OLIN HALL OF ENGINEERING. Built in 1974 with funds from the Olin Foundation, to house chemical engineering and materials science. Photo by John Halliburton.
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240
VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240
COMPUTER CENTER. 1963. A unit of the Stevenson Center for the Natural Sciences. Houses the DECSYSTEM-1099 computer system for use by the students, faculty, and administration. Photo by Gerard Holly.
Ariel view of Vanderbilt University Campus, showing the women’s dormitory, Branscomb Quadrangle in the foreground
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240

MARGARET AND HARVY BRANSCOMB QUADRANGLE, named for Vanderbilt’s fourth chancellor and his wife. Dining hall and four connected dormitory buildings: LUPTON, VAUGHN, STAPLETON, and SCALES houses, named for four early Vanderbilt women. Photo by Gerald Holly.

TOLMAN HALL. Dormitory. Named for Herbert Cushing Tolman, professor of Greek, founder of the Vanderbilt chapter of Phi Beta Kappa and dean of the College of Arts and Science from 1914 to 1923. Photo by Gerald Holly.

DIVINITY SCHOOL QUADRANGLE. Classrooms, offices, refectory, Benton Chapel (named for Dean John Keith Benton who led the school from 1939 until his death in 1956). Financed by University funds and a number of gifts.

BENTON CHAPEL, a part of the John Frederick Oberlin Divinity quadrangle. Oberlin College Graduate School of Theology merged with Vanderbilt Divinity School in 1966. Chapel is named for John Keith Benton, Divinity School Dean 1939-56.

OWEN GRADUATE SCHOOL OF MANAGEMENT is named for Lulu Hampton Owen and Ralph Owen of Nashville Mechanical Engineering Hall, built in 1888 and now listed in National Register of Historic Places, has been incorporated into the modern (1982) Owen School complex. Photo by J. Clark Thomas.

THE OLD GYM. Built in 1880, a gift from William H. Vanderbilt, son of the University’s founder. Listed in the National Register of Historic Places. Interior of the original building was remodeled in 1961 to house the Department of Fine Arts Gallery. Photo by Gerald Holly.
BUTTRICK HALL. Built in 1928 and named for Wallace Buttrick, an officer of the General Education Board. Houses the Department of General Biology. Photo by Gerald Holly.
STUDENT UNION BUILDING. Student Union Building houses Cafeteria, Snack Shop, Book Store and recreational facilities.
GODCHAUX HALL. 1925. School of Nursing. Named for Mary Ragland Godchaux. A $1,000,000 under-ground addition was completed in 1978.
KISSAM QUADRANGLE
DORMITORY, VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY. NASHVILLE, TENN.
ALUMNI MEMORIAL HALL. Recreation and assembly rooms for students and faculty. Given by Alumni as a memorial to 44 Vanderbilt men who gave their lives in World War 1.

RAND HALL, VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY. Main dining hall of the University, campus bookstore and post office. This building was named for Frank Chambless Rand, 1898, president of the Board of Trust from 1935 to 1949. Alumni and other friends contributed about half the cost.
LINE UP OF VANDERBILT FOOTBALL TEAM OF
DUDLEY FIELD. Home of the Vanderbilt Commodores. Built in 1922, the stadium was renovated and expanded in 1982, now seats 41,135 spectators. Photo by J. Clark Thomas.
Dudley Field and Memorial Gymnasium
Vanderbilt University–Nashville, Tenn.

BLAIR SCHOOL OF MUSIC was merged with Vanderbilt University in 1981. Established in 1964 through a bequest of Valere Blair Potter in memory of her mother, Myra Jackson Blair, the school was first a division of Peabody College. Private institution from 1977 until merger with Vanderbilt. Photo by John Halliburton.

STATUE OF COMMODORE CORNELIUS VANDERBILT by Italian sculptor Giuseppe Moretti stands in front of Kirkland Hall, at entrance to Vanderbilt University campus. Commodore Vanderbilt gave a million dollars in 1873 to build and endow the University, with the wish that it would “contribute to strengthening the ties which should exist between all sections of our common country.” Photo by Sallie India Linebaugh.
Spring Arrives on Campus

note.p: Dogwoods in bloom brighten our 3300acre grounds in early spring, heralding the longer, warmer days to come in Nashville.

did.unittitle: AN OASIS IN THE CITY

note.p: Vanderbilt University’s lush landscape mixes towering trees, winding paths, and spacious lawns with historic and current architecture.

did.unittitle: 24. Nashville: With Flounces, garlands, and pointed toes, these children danced at a Vanderbilt reunion in 1925.
26. Nashville: “The Campus” grill is still on 21st Avenue South across from the Vanderbilt campus.
25. Nashville: Professor Walter Storer photographed this fire destroying Vanderbilt’s Wesley Hall, 19 February 1932.
Aerial View- Vanderbilt University
Nashville, Tennessee

Vanderbilt University. The Commodore’s Statue. Nashville citizens subscribed to pay for the statue of the University’s founder, Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. It was installed on campus in 1897 and faced east. In 1949, the Commodore “turned around” to face north when the main entrance to the campus was placed on West End Avenue.
Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37240

note.p: Tennessee General Assembly dedication to Mr. Vanderbilt- Photo by Will and Deni McIntyre.

did.unittitle: Statue of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt

note.p: Vanderbilt University is a private, comprehensive teaching and research university with undergraduate, graduate, and professional programs. It has over 1,600 full-time faculty and diverse student body of about 9,700. Vanderbilt was founded in 1873 with a gift from Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt.

did.unittitle: KIRKLAND HALL

note.p: Kirkland Hall’s bronze bell sounds the hours from its distinctive tower. Named in 1939 for James H. Kirkland, Vanderbilt’s second Chancellor, the building houses administrative offices including the office of the Chancellor.
